awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Constantly on the Lookout: Low-Cost Sensor Enabled Explosive Detection to Protect High Density Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to empower ordinary citizens to take charge in collecting real time environmental data that can be used to serve a common interest. The target application of the project is a cyber-physical system for detecting small amounts of explosive vapor in the air so as to protect large-area public gatherings. In this system, extremely low-cost explosive sensors, handed out free of charge, will be connected to the smart phones of the willing participants, effectively turning each one of them into a look-out sensor node. Although the primary application of the proposed cyber-physical system is explosive detection, problems with similar technical challenges include air pollution monitoring systems, pandemic prevention, fire and/or gas leak monitoring. Successful completion of this project will generate a plethora of new applications that target problems with the aim of reaching a common goal by leveraging computation, power, and communications capacities donated by willing participants. Understanding that interest in STEM (science, technology, engineering, math)-related careers begins in elementary school, the project will use a sensor-based system that aims at locating a heat source, as part of K-12 outreach activities that explore crowd-sourced data collection, processing, and scheduling. The researchers work regularly with undergraduate and high school students through Fulton Undergraduate Research Initiative (FURI), Barrett Summer Scholars (BSS), National Science Foundation-sponsored National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network Research Experience for Undergraduates (NNIN REU), and Arizona State University's Summer Research Experience for High School Students program.

Designing a system based on extremely low-cost sensors for crowd-sourced monitoring has several unique technical and scientific challenges that the project tackles. First, cost/power requirements and the need to detect tiny amounts of explosive vapor are at odds with each other. Second, the system will be designed to tolerate inevitable sensor inaccuracies and false positives/negatives in a stable manner. Third, since the entire system hinges on willing participation from the public, sensor operation will be made transparent to the user, and not create a negative user experience. Finally, privacy concerns of the users will be addressed by keeping them anonymous, and the security threats generated by this anonymity will be addressed.

por.por_cntn:
This CPS project aims at developing the scientific framework for and engineering of a cyber-physical system for securing high-density public gatherings at low-cost, by leveraging computational and communication resources donated by the participants. The proposed cyber-physical system is made up of large numbers of ordinary people using small, low-cost sensors coupled to smart phones with the necessary computation and communication capabilities; security officers equipped with more sensitive and expensive detectors; and one or more servers to process the data, make decisions, and direct security officers.

At the University of Delaware, we have made a simulator implementation of the proposed CPS, created to test and design data processing, energy saving, and false positive mitigation strategies. Our simulator makes full utilization of realistic diffusion values of explosive chemical vapor, generated from the COMSOL simulator. To simulate crowd movements around an area, it integrates the MENGE Movement Simulator into our environment, which can integrate routing of users between different points of interest, individual state machines for each crowd member, and implement intelligent control of each pedestrian. Our simulator adopts a fully event driven structure that allows for complex behaviors that happen at differing time sales. Events can be scheduled at any time, with millisecond level accuracy. To explore the large design space, our simulator is designed for massively parallel simulations, and features a complete logging solution and a mostly automated statistics generation process.

At the University of Delaware, we have developed several algorithms for data collecting and processing, energy saving, and false positive mitigation. Regarding crowd-based threat detection, sensor drifting causes a large number of false positives in raw data. To overcome this challenge, we treat the sensors as a population, and exploit both spatial and temporal information for outlier detection. We implemented and evaluated two detection algorithms: a Validator Based Detection algorithm and a grid-based detection algorithm. Our results show that the grid-based detection algorithm is more accurate.

Regrading energy saving, the fundamental goal is to keep the most nodes participating. We have developed adaptive sampling and clustering algorithms to maximize the efficiency of sensor usage. Our algorithms combine both speed based and density based adaptive sampling to increasing coverage while saving energy. Our design further saves energy by forming “clusters” with heads that report to the server via WiFi or 5G and members that report to the cluster head via Bluetooth. To improve the energy efficiency of our clusters in the face of ad-hoc node movement, we have designed a combination of local and global cluster reformation (reclustering) procedures.

Regrading routing of supernode (i.e., security officers equipped with more sensitive and expensive detectors), we have developed a K-Means clustering algorithm that dynamically adapts to the number of supernodes as well as the geometry of the area. Intelligent shortest path calculations are created when supernodes are assigned more than one location to minimize travel distance. We further created ‘idle behavior’ for supernodes which guides them to patrol their regions searching for bomb locations. Preliminary results demonstrate rapid response time and bomb detection via idle behavior.

All the algorithms developed in this project have been incorporated into the open-source simulator implementation of the proposed CPS. We tested our system-level simulator described with a scenario created to mimic the last 800m of the Boston Marathon. Pedestrians arrive into either the northern or the southern region of the simulated area via entry points at the border of the simulation. Each pedestrian’s move pattern follows a state machine.

The project has offered extensive training opportunities to both undergraduate and graduate students. Ten undergraduates have been involved in the project, and three of them are from minority and underrepresented groups. The project has supported three graduate students towards their PhD and MS degrees. The PI has incorporated project results into the graduate course she taught in the University of Delaware, offering comprehensive training to students and bringing students up to the research frontier.
